												Tokyo Drift? Initial D? VDrift? If anything of this appeals to you, this might too.In any case, this game's remarkable. It's challenging, exciting and unforgiving. But let me tell you, it's just as satisfying once you get a feel for it.You start out in a minimalistic world, sitting in the infamous Toyota Trueno AE86. Your destiny? Drift. A brief tutorial follows, which will probably result in you crashing into walls a lot, but that's fine, as nothing else really is needed to understand how this game works! The game then releases you into a free-roaming environment with a few missions you have to do to unlock more stages. You can then also select stages, cars and tracks once in Free-roam mode, a bit like in NFS or other racing titles.As you get more familiar with the controls, the stages get more exciting and challenging/longer. They also come in several formats: Lap-based drift-tracks, Driftkhana, which is a highscore time-attack inside an arena, or mountain sprint tracks. The goal is always the same, drift gracefully, score points, interact with objects such as poles to drift past or boxes to shatter, add that up to the final score and remain away from hitting walls or losing your combo. Sounds easier than it is, trust me, the Japanese themed tracks and names will kick into your curb at first.That said, car handling is the key, each car has their own way of handling, so finding what suits you most will be the way to go. Ontop of that, drifting's the deal, so going fast won't always be the key to success either. Manual or automatic shifting? How high should be the turning sensitivity? Well, all these factors will help you optimize your driving style, making it possible to reach up to be the drift king.I personally had, and will have a blast with this title in the future. It's been a while since I found an appealing drifting/racing experience and I can safely say this game has done it right. Now go... Go... and be the next Drift-King.

												Absolute Drift is a *gasp* drifting game. Of course the most important part of a vehicle game of any sort are the controls. I will admit that the controls in Absolute Drift are quite tight while the driving itself does feel a bit too slippery, but as you might guess it’s not a big deal in a game where your only goal is to slide stylishly. Absolute Drift also boasts a unique Japanified minimalist aesthetic, paying homage to one of the origins of the drifting motorsport. It isn’t all roses but let’s not hesitate to pop the hood and see what we got, this is Absolute Drift.Free Roam mode serves as the Story Mode, and will serve to introduce you to the controls as well as different challenges and events. After spinning out a few times and learning the art of counter-steering you will begin to grasp what the game is really all about and because there is very little hand-holding, conquering a world challenge or topping the global highscore for any track feels like a great accomplishment. Absolute Drift has a total of 23 tracks to enjoy; 10 circuit Drift tracks, 9 open-world Driftkhana courses, and 4 one-way Mountain Drift tracks, so you can find the event that suits you best.While the world challenges and events have as much variety as can be expected, I find that it still isn’t quite enough. Drift around this, drift between that, it isn’t until the last stage that things start getting really interesting. All I’m saying is I wanted to jump on a few more roofs. Car customization is limited to 6 body-types, which all have a slightly different feel. You can also pick a color and a decal, but nothing beyond that. I would really like a chance to fine-tune my engine and shocks. Stripped-down customization and lack of real-time damage are gigantic missed opportunities.I enjoyed my time with Absolute Drift, with its low-key dance music soundtrack, inoffensive looks, and high degree of mastery. Lack of customization and content hurts replayability, but the difficulty curve and global scoreboards means it still has quite a bit to offer. The story mode can be completed in around 2 hours, and if that’s all you’re buying this game for then $12 might be a bit overpriced. It is a bit of a one-trick pony, but it does that trick extremely well. If you’re in the mood for a score-attack drifting game, give Absolute Drift a try. Though it might be worth waiting for a sale. Big thanks to Funselektor Labs for the review copy! So, here it is. My review.At time of posting, I have all the achievements and have 50 hours in the game.First of all, just a general comment: I love this game. It has a great, smooth game engine and the controls are fairly easy to me. It wasn't too hard to pick up, and learning some drifiting from Assetto Corsa and driving my Miata IRL, I can say that the physics are very realistic and it's easy to apply those skills into this game.Here's a list for the TL:DR, and it's at the top (you're welcome):Pros:- Smooth Game Engine- Difficulty Settings are Spot On- Controls on Every Difficultly Setting are Great- Music is Great (Especially C41; sorry Nyte, your music is still great, lol)- Colors are Great- Online Leaderboards- Fairly wide selection of Maps- Driftkhana, Drift Tracks, and Mtn Drift settings are awesome to choose from- Game is Updated at a Good Pace- Game as a Whole was Tailored for a Wide audience- Wide Range of Adjustable Graphics Settings to Fit your Performance Needs- Different cars fit different people, but aren't too unbalanced in terms of full capabilites.- Free-Roam. Yesssssss...- Less than 500 MB (currently)- Very Fair and Rewarding Point system that pushes you to try harderCons:- Non-customizable Controls (Steam Controller's Reprogramming Defeats this Con)- No-multiplayer, yet (for reasons)Otherwise, this game is perfect in my opinion.Okay, now the novel:Personal CommentsI have owned this game since August 2015 and have really been off and on with it. I can tell you that once I got a Steam Controller, everything changed, and I loved how the game played with it. Honestly, I couldn't play it on anything but the highest difficulty. PhysicsThe physics are phenomenal. I don't think I have ever played such an arcad-ey styled game with such realistic physics. It totally replicates real life (or damn near it) and the developer did such a great job with it. From what I have seen, there are no current bugs in the game's physics and I see no reason for the physics to be modified at all.GraphicsThe graphics are great aswell. I think that the color theme is perfect for the (not so much) "JDM/Dorifto" and (but more) Japan feel. It is a little brutal on the eyes when you're in a dark room or are very tired, but otherwise, it is very fun and keeps you alert. I really enjoy how the tire marks work. They really help when you are drifitng if you need to see if you're angle is going too far (genenrally more than 90º), and they look cool. The graphics, in general, may seem a little bland at times, but it really keeps you focused on what you're doing. Plus, this game isn't really about looks, it's more about the gameplay.Gameplay/ControlsAny kind of controller (I use a Steam Controller) is nearly a must. Keyboard is simply not enough to fully enjoy and get good at this game, but it is still playable. It really sucks that you can't change the controls in game, but the Steam Remapping or something like motioninjoy could help with that. The actual controlling on all difficulties is great and accurate to their names. The hardest difficulty feels butter smooth and is what I use all the time. If you take your time, you can really learn the game and get good with a car that fits you. I personally work well with "The Original," but who knows what you might be great with. Also, there is always a mixture of challenging yourself, the music, and the map you're on that can give you different moods within the game.This game is also very fun and easy to get back into and keep with. I think that in general, it may get boring after you completely master (rank 1) all of the maps and finish the campaign, but it would take a long time (probably no less than 150 hours) before you get to that point. At least for me, the game pushes me to try harder and be the best at any map I try. I am currently, as of this review, number 4 on Mt. Nikko with about 300,000 points to go to number 1. It's taken me about 15 hours to get to that point and I don't plan on stopping until I am at number 1.Last WordsThis game is ♥♥♥♥ing amazing. I don't even think curse words can explain how awesome this game is. I think that the game has come a very long way in the past 9 months and I think that it has amazing potential. funselektorlabs deserves a lot of credit for the creation of this game. I can't wait to see how this game evolves because it would be a shame if it were to stop where it is. However, it wouldn't be horrible because the game is already amazing as-is.--------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------Points SystemThe point system is very fair and I think I have it figured out, in general. Here's my thoughts:- Depending on drifting direction, a sideways-sliding score is given, and it's when the most rear wheel in a drift (if you're going right, it's the rear right) is farther out than the forward wheel (if you're drifting around a right corner, it's your left front, and vice-versa):- This is the general "drifitng score."- The wider the angle up to a 90º drift is more points- You get a multiplier based upon how long you have been drifing "continuously"- If you're going too slow, the points stop adding- If you go over 90º, the points stop adding- If you hit anything, except bonuses, your points are summed in the total and you lose your multiplier- If you stop drifing for too long (I think about 5 seconds), your points are summed in the total and you lose your multiplier- Extra points are given when you go around a bonus pole:- The closer you are, the more points you get- The faster you are going, the more points you get- If you're too far away or "aren't drifitng" near one, it doesn't count- If you hit one, it doesn't count, but doesn't get rid of your score or multiplier- Extra points are given when you hit a red block:- If you hit it you get points- If you don't hit it, you get no points- Faster and more Sideways you are, you get more points- Extra points are given when you go around a donut circle (driftkhana only):- If you finish the donut indicated with the increasing red circle, you get more points- Faster and more Sideways you are, you get more points- If you hit it, you get no points- Extra points are given when you spin in a "spin-zone" (driftkhana only):- If you finish the spinning indicated with the increasing red circle, you get more points- There's really no downside to these...- Points are inceased exponentially (I don't know how much the curve is) if you stack bonuses in one "continuous" drift:- If you keep getting bonuses, they'll exponentially increase- If your current score is reset, so does your bonus stack

												Absolute Drift is one of the best drifting and car related games ever made. If not THE best.  The game is incredibly simple at face value, which lends to the game being both aesthetically and mechanically perfect. Its top down perspective and simple visuals work fantastic together. You get a broad view of your canvas, allowing you to cut amazing drifts and prepare where to go to create the best line. The cars to choose from (including a BMW, an AE-86, a Supra, all made as generic cars with nods to their real life counterparts) are incredible. Again- all this is due to its simplicity, and the simplicity was very goal driven by design. When you look at your car- it gives the same feelings you had with your Hotwheels as a kid, they all control as people expect them to (The AE-86 is so well balanced it's essentially all I use, just like the the real life Toyota is percieved to be) .... They perform as your tool to navigate the perfect drift, and at the same time they are the tip of your paint brush that is marking the canvas laid out before you- painting the world in black ink as you weave and arc your way around- the sound of your rev pinging and tires squeeling as you yank the E-Brake and swing back the other way is spot on. //Drifting as an art.That's the beauty of this game. It gets Drift culture better than any other video game before it. It doesn't slap you in the face with popular culture, icons, brands... It bleeds the emotion and style of Drifting, and that's it. The only real world reference beyond the cars themselves, are the Torii that dot the landscape, which are the gateways to the next chapter in free-roam... And the japanese chimes that play as you make your way to the next level. (Remember their use in this? 


YouTube™ Video: Tokyo Drift - Teriyaki Boyz [ MUSIC VIDEO ] HD 

			Views: 36,328,278		

			Fast and Furious Tokyo Drift - Teriyaki Boyz		

 ...Fantastic)  The Japanese imagery and use of a paint-brush on canvas visual style bleeds Drifting as an art form. A pure form of expression through controlling a car. It's respectful to the art, but mechanically this is incredible as well. //Pitch perfect Drifting mechanicsThe game will start you off and tell you how to drift- it puts you through a simple tutorial before letting you loose on this clean playground- a playground with real world objects... Ferris wheels that make me think of the pier in LA, train yards and other construction type objects that help me to imagine drifting in big open back lots late at night. It's all so clean and perfect that  much like reading a book, it allows you to fill in the blanks with your own perception of the craft. Just the way it should be. But again, the craft itself is just as important- and the tutorial gets you on the path and then drops you in to learn the rest yourself. The other major part of pure drift-culture is failure and success. Learning your car, learning physical limitations, tinkering with your setup (in this case the controls to match your comfort, turn sensitivity and "difficulty" which to me is more of a way that the car acts- try medium and hard as well, as you may find the car acts a bit more like it should in your mind) ... Failing and trying again until you learn how to drift and master a course. That's the thing about drifting and people who actually do it. It's a comradery thing- it's something you don't learn over night, it's not all about showing off and looking "hella dope" ... It's about mastering something with a deep learning curve and perfecting it. It's about risk and reward. For a top-down arcade style racer, this game allows you to do just that, while still BEING A VIDEO GAME and not a NASA-sponsored sim of the craft itself. I can't say this enough, aesthetically and mechanically this game NAILS the art and culture of drifting better than any game before it, and likely after it too.//Presentation is everythingAnd present it does. It is effortless here. No obnoxious menus to slog through. You can go back to the main menu from a course in free-roam nearly instantly, and the music doesn't change either. That's a BIG thing too. The music is perfect ambient EDM tracks. All majorly chill. They all fit and hit the modern car-culture perfectly and enhance your driving experience while doing it. The first track to start when I loaded up the game the first time was perfect- with an awesomely simple title splash that slides perfectly into the game as you hit Enter... The game feels perfectly put together. Every piece fits seamlessly... And as I swap to a different mode or back out and the music doesn't suddenly cut or change- that helps to make the package feel that much more "whole" and perfect.Simplicity here is key. The game doesn't use simplicity to hide faults it possibly could have if they added more- it uses it so that you notice and gravitate to the things you SHOULD while playing it. The mechanics and ink-brush style of your drift. It's zen. Absolute Drift is Zen. Fun to play for a couple minutes while waiting for your friends to get grouped for a dungeon in WoW or Competitive CS GO. Fun to play with your coffee while you wake up. Fun to just play for hours with no interest in doing anything else- just to top the leaderboards or channel your inner DK. Absolute Drift is just that- Absolute Drift.

												I've had tears of joy playing this game to completion, which is a rarity, I will say.Absolute Drift is a top down, minimalistic stunt driving game. Your goal: become a master drifter, by refining the art of spinning out and smashing into walls controlling oversteer and burning rubber.For the aesthetics: it's low poly, simple graphics, with most buildings and roads left white and untextured. Objects of interest are coloured red, blue or yellow. Your car leaves behind skidmarks wherever it goes, whether you slide or not, which allows for impressive drawings on tarmac, or a nice spiral when you catch some big air.The soundtrack is a relaxing, upbeat electronic and DnB by Nyte and C41 respectively - which fits the near zen-like atmosphere of the game. Cars have simple, but distinct engine noises, with more subtle transmission whine or turbo flutter.The gameplay is the purest I've seen in modern driving games. It's you, your car, your skills and the track. Whether free-roaming, doing driftkhanas or mountain drifts, almost everything revolves around getting your back end slideways and very, very smokey. You have a selection of 6 cars to choose from, each performing differently from one another - some are heavier, some are more stable, some are more tail happy. All can be repainted and given a little livery. You'll spend most of your time smacking against walls drifting in an open-ended hub world, peppered with missions to perform - stuff like "drift between this and this" or "donut around this". Finishing the campaign takes around 1.5 hours, but you also have specific tracks - the aforementioned driftkhanas, mountain drifts and circuit drifts, containing Steam leaderboards that will push you to improve your scores.Let's not beat around the bush; the game is hard. The handling is intentionally challenging. Unless you're careful, it doesn't matter whether you use the gamepad or the keyboard, you WILL spin out and hit walls, and the game knows it. There are several difficulty settings to pick from, which change how grippy your car is, but above all, mastery of counter-steer, weight transfer, grip limit, torque and gearing is paramount to any decent drifting in this world. This results in one of the most satisfying moments I've ever experienced in videogames: the flow of stringing together perfect drifts through a tight and twisty track, losing as little momentum as possible and rocketing to the top. The execution of the handling is absolutely STELLAR.The game has finally been upgraded to the Zen Edition, bringing forth a new event type - Midnight Drifts, which are really really challenging! In addition, you have Event Challenges to unlock said Midnight Drifts, REPLAYS and GHOSTS on the tracks! This is the kind of free content that will exponentially boost the game's longevity, even if a level editor or proper multiplayer still don't quite exist yet. I'd liken this game as the Portal of driving games: a clean art style, a short campaign that doesn't overstay its welcome, if it's not over too quick, a dash of humour and one of the best (top down, minimalistic, very very slideways) driving experiences I've had in my long years of driving/racing games. I f-ing love it!Get it ASAP if you like/love cars, but even if you don't it's worth a try for the experience and the challenging but rewarding gameplay.

"Absolute Drift" Review *Disclaimer: This game was purchased for personal use, not provided by a developer. Absolute Drift, herein abbreviated as AD, is essentially a minimalistic casual driving game. You play from a 3D, third person “top-down” perspective, as you traverse 7 worlds completing various drifting tasks. The goal? Become a master drifter, sliding over water and doing donuts around Ferris Wheels. Here are a few things worth noting. Art Style The elegant contrast of white landscapes against bright red obstacles is the key idea behind the art style of AD. The graphics look gorgeous with their minimalistic textures and subtle physics. As you drive through stacks of blocks, you’ll be blown away at how the particles just seem to fall away without hesitation. The soundtrack is perfectly suited for the game, and huge props to the artists for their great work in that department. Difficulty The game seems simple at first – get your car sideways, countersteer, and you’re set. It’s not quite that easy. In free roam you will learn how to stay in drifts and exit the drift whenever you need to. Meanwhile, you can use various events to hone your skills on-track. There’s no difficulty toggle here – in events you are ranked against other players in global and friend-based rankings. Length, Story, Etc. One of the only gripes I had with this game was the length of the free roam world. There are seven “worlds” you go through before having to resort to replaying tracks over and over just to beat your own times. I would love to see a co-op or even online 1-on-1 game mode in this, and it would definitely give it a bit more reason to play beyond free-roam. Performance AD runs phenomenally on my rig, as I expected. However, as with all my reviews, I tested the game on Intel Integrated Graphics to see how well it would do for casual gamers. It ran at a solid 35 or so fps, definitely within a playable range. You could likely push it to 50 by playing 1280x720 windowed.Do I like this game? Absolutely. (Pardon the pun) I would recommend it to anyone looking for a game that they can complete with 100% achievements in less than 5 hours. If you liked this review or want to see more recommended games, be sure to follow our curator group: Follow Original Curator GroupCurator text: Absolute Drift is a masterpiece with its elegant graphics and fantastic physics. Highly recommended.

												I didn't know anything about Absolute Drift before buying it, but I knew I liked racing, drifting and that this game had a large portion of positive reviews. So I thought, "why not?". Here's what I think of this game after a few hours of play:Graphics: I've always been a huge fan of minimalist/subtle designs, and Absolute Drift pretty much nails that. Everything has a low polygon count. The track is white, the important things are red and the death zone (water) is blue. This very small color palette is great because you can very quickly understand any situation you are in, but it also carries a message that, I think, translates the game well: "No BS, just drifting".The black skidmarks felt kind of strange at first because they are here even when not drifting, but then I understood they were here to serve as a visualization of your driving, because they contrast the pure white track. By simply looking at the skidmarks, you can judge how well your took that last corner. More simply, it just looks nice.On a more technical aspect, at the time I am writing this, the game is very poor. The graphical options are very limited: no custom resolutions, no V-Sync and the graphical quality is limited to a few presets, which means you can't set the anti-aliasing, texture filtering, etc. on your own. Then again, the game launched very recently, so I have faith the developer will add those options later.Audio: The cars sound good, you can really feel how powerful they are when accelerating and the hissing sound of the tires when drifting is satisfying. The soundtrack blends in very well with the game. It's all electro music (like Drum & Bass), but all of the tracks are very calm. It was a good choice to make the soundtrack relaxing because the player will spend a lot of time failing and retrying, but the tranqulity of those tunes help remain calm.Gameplay: Here comes the most important part, and fortunately, it's the best. The control scheme is pretty much what you'd expect in any driving game: Left-Right-Accelerate-Brake-Handrake-Gear up-Gear down. Learning how the game works takes two minutes at worst, but knowing how to handle the cars themselves is a harder task. You cannot make a normal turn in this game, you will always slide. On top of that, the cars feel very heavy: even when you think you're going pretty slow, drifting will barely make you deccelerate and you will very often end up in a wall because of that at the beginning. When you get the hang of this, however, driving becomes a very smooth experience. You can easily chain multiple drifts and properly gauge acceleration/decceleration.The developper made the very interesting decision of only giving the player an isometric point of view instead of the good old 1st/3rd person cameras you can find in other racing games. It's quite useful because it allows the player to see further ahead than they normally could, and plan their drifts in consequence.Content: The game is split in two modes: Free-roam, where you drive in open spaces completing missions (which usually are "drift near this", "donut around that", etc.) to open new worlds where you complete more missions, and Events where you can choose to play on either Tracks (with 3 laps), Driftkhanas (small, open spaces where you must score as many points as possible in 2 minutes) and Mountain Drifts (tracks where you drift downhill to the end). There is, at the time of writing, 5 worlds and 24 tracks. The 5 worlds can be completed in about an hour or two and each world also unlocks various Events and one car.Something unfortunate is that all cars are, unless I have not played enough to realize the difference, model+sound swaps. It would have been nice to give all cars a different handling, but perhaps the dev will add this in the future.The good thing about Events is their replayability and the presence of a Leaderboards system. If you want to climb that ladder you will have to master every corner of every track, which is not an issue given how good the cars feel. The large amount of hours sinkable justifies, I believe, the price tag.One thing I would really love to see is the addition of a map maker (perhaps with Workshop integration) in order to enhance the lifespan of this game.In conclusion, I would definitely recommend this little gem if you are the kind of person who likes spending a large amount of time on a single game in order to master it.

												Absolute Drift is an interesting top down car game, that focuses much more on drifting and the control of the car, rather than racing. You'll be doing your best to drift around corners, doing donuts, and fish tails in order to score as much points and to accomplish as much tasks as possible.


YouTube™ Video: Absolute Drift: Impressions (Drift driving adventure game, indie,  gameplay, and review) 

			Views: 1,568		

			Absolute Drift: Impressions (Drift driving adventure game, indie, gameplay, and review) Absolute Drift is an interesting top down driving indie game, that focuses on drifting more than racing.		

Once in the game you'll be thrown into a somewhat open world where you'll be doing various tasks, such as ramp jumping, donuts, fish tails, and other drifting and driving challenges. Once the section of the map's tasks are complete, it'll open up new areas of the game. While exploring this semi-open world, you'll also be given the opportunity to enter one of it's many mini-missions where you'll be aiming for high scores on the leader board. The game also features multiple car models, and colour and pattern customization as well.The biggest hurdle to Absolute Drift is it's learning curve. It's not an easy game to master and make little concession to beginning or even intermediate players. The controls are difficult at first, as the car feel very differnt from other driving games, and the ground feels something like ice. Spinning out and losing control of your car will probably be your first 30 minutes or more of your experiance. This might prove frustrating to players who don't play a lot of driving games (like me) but when you start to get the hang of things, and the small amounts of progress that you make in your driving ability really does feel rewarding. Get to the zone, complete objectives, unlock the next one - repeat until you're the drift master. Events are instances in which you can rack up your personal score and compete with other players via the leaderboards. You have 3 lap drift courses of varying difficulty, driftkhanas, which essentially are closed off arenas in which you race against time to get the highest score possible and you have drift tracks in which you go from point A to point B and get as many points as you can along the way. The game is short, if you're aiming to 'complete' it. If you're here for the pleasure of drifting though, you can spend hours upon hours perfecting your skills. The presentation is fantastic with very slick, clean and, most importantly, clear visuals. Music is very catchy and complements the picture in the best possible way. All in all - if you like stylish visuals, racing and drifting, treat yourself with this little gem.

Recovering from a spin is a hassle, you can't quickly go reverse-turn-forward using the car's inertia (and same for the other way around).Regarding controls, having multiple layout for controllers is better, but still, none of them suited me. I would have prefered to have the option to set the handbrake as LT. I personally can't handle acceleration + handbrake with the same hand. So I ended up only using acceleration and rarely brake/reverse. And you still can't change the settings while racing or free-roaming. And you can't reset the settings either.So eventhough this update has brought improvements to the game, it hasn't done so for it's core gameplay. 												Sometimes in your haste to enjoy a game, you don't give it a good chance. My first time playing this game (well, maybe my first hour) was me being really frustrated at not being able to drift, not being able to control my car, and generally not being able to make it the way I wanted. I pictured a game that was more about relaxing and leisurely drifting through tracks or endless highways, but was wrong.The thing is, I don't mind being wrong; Absolute Drift has a great mechanics system that rewards you for putting time in and learning how your car works. This is likely as close to it comes to the real world, too, as no one is necessarily a Drift King the first time they try. The more time I spent tweaking the settings (note: you may find Hard controls with 100% steering sensitivity better if you're used to drifting in other Arcade-y racers) the more I felt myself gradually getting better.The cool thing is, every time I boot the game up now I genuinely need to warm up, as my first ten minutes are me reacclimating to how my car controls. This isn't a bad thing at all; again, it rewards patience and persistence, and the first time you actually do pull off something awesome (be it a chain drift, or even a drift that's challenging things a little too far) you feel amazing.Essentially this game rewards mastery of the mechanics and the time it takes to learn them. My main complaints are that I could do without the time limits, objectives and feedback during some event courses: I would love to be able to turn it off and just practice drifting (or just doing it therapeutically) without the game telling me I'm dropping combos or running out of time.I also think this game (especially when it's called a Zen Edition) could use some procedurally-generated endless highway that either has a difficulty you specify or one that changes organically; I LOVE the mountain and midnight courses in this game, but find them woefully too short.Great game, but you need to be patient with it. If you do, you'll find awesome, rewarding moments.

												Review in a few: 


YouTube™ Video: Review in a Few: Absolute Drift 

			Views: 27		

			Here is my review in a few for Absolute Drift: Zen Edition Buy the game here: store.steampowered.com/app/320140/ My written review can be found on steam here:...		

+Visuals+Soundtrack+Steam Controller+Mad Drifts+Leaderboard asyncronous multiplayer.-No storyAbsolute Drift is a game about a man with a family to save from the Yakuza and the only bid they’ll take on their lives is if you beat their leader in a drift-off, so you play a montage of training until the final battle scene like every kung fu movie.  Wait that’s not right…  So there’s no backstory.  You’re just a car with mad drifts.It’s a very simple concept, drift as much as you can, chain together drifts, and get points.  The more points you get, the higher your score, the farther up the leaderboards you go.  There’s a large open-world area where you can complete challenges like drifting around certain objects, performing jumps, and collecting spinning plus-signs.  It’s sectioned off into areas, and you must complete objectives in each area before advancing to the next one resulting in solid progression as your personal skill improves.There are dedicated tracks with leaderboards (as mentioned earlier) that allow you to compete against others asynchronously, which are placed around the open world map for you to find.  If exploration is less your thing however, you can find the tracks on the main menu as well and jump right in.  These tracks can have one of two types: open areas with trick spots, and race tracks that record both your time and your drifts.The controls are easy to pick up, tough to master -- Or maybe I just suck.  It’s definitely not a game to play keyboard only, as feathering drifts is nigh impossible, so a controller of some form is a must.  It also has some really nice feedback on how good your drift is through rumble, which translates well onto a steam controller.Graphics wise, it’s visually pleasing.  It’s very easy to tell what is where and what’s important, and there is never enough on screen to get busy.  With a pleasantly good looking drift line showing your mad skills, you can watch your past as you tear up the present.Overall it’s an enjoyable game and worth picking up on sale for a few hours of fun.  It’s not going to keep you gripped for a dozen hours, but it’s better than your average movie with a lower admittance fee.

This isn't a drifting simulator. This isn't a racing game. This is a chilled out explorer and you play the role of an AE86.I hope they make Absolute Drift 2 and give more substance. An ability to modify the car that would have an effect on the physics would be cool as well as camera angles. Obviously multiplayer for some door-on-door drifing action would be great and anything to make this a game that you'd want to go back to once you unlocked everything that needed to be unlocked.Is it worth US$11.99? 												This is a really fun game, reminiscent of Drift Legends, a game I used to play on iPhone.It doesn't hold your hand; it gives you a few pointers, and then lets you get into it.For most people who play car games on a regular basis, it's easy to get into, but still hard to master. I've played about 7hrs, and seen all there is, the only thing to keep me coming back is to increase my scores on levels.Conclusion: great little drift game, definitely worth playing. 												I’m usually not much a fan of driving games these days. I used to play them a lot more when I was younger but at some point I just stopped having fun facing the same challenges again and again in every driving game. But I did enjoy drifting mechanics from time to time and since I got this game in a Humble Bundle, I decided to check it out.Unfortunately, I can’t really say I was having a great time with it. The first problem I had with the game were the controls. Giving cars realistic physical properties is difficult and more importantly, difficult for the player to control. Which is why most driving games focus on fun, arcadey feeling driving that doesn’t challenge the player too much with real world physics. Absolute Drift unfortunately goes a completely different route, eschewing physical car mechanics as well as typical tightly controlled driving of other games. Your car is almost always drifting. You can barely drive in a straight line and then enter a curve without the car breaking out at the back. This is also explained by the extremely wide turning radius that you drive while trying your best not to break out.Then again, drifting is the main attraction of this game so it makes somewhat sense for your car to be easily turned sideways. The problem is that the controls feel extremely floaty. Acceleration is slow as if your car weighs twice as much as a real car. And I sort of suspect that may be the case, since the easiest way to get a physics engine to behave this erratic is by increasing the mass of an object and then increasing the torque of the motor providing it with energy. This leads to very hard to learn drifting mechanics that can lead to much frustration. And I know some people will inevitably like it this way, if the scores on the leaderboards are anything to go by. But I just found it annoying. And this leads me to my next complaint: The camera. The game utilizes a bird’s-eye perspective which means when you’re driving towards the camera the controls are reversed and foreshortening makes it difficult to make out where you are in relation to the borders of the tracks. I would’ve much preferred a typical racing game camera hovering behind the car or at least one that follows the rotation of your car.But all of that could be forgiven if the game had actual content. Unfortunately, it doesn’t. There are plenty of levels there. But drifting around them is the only thing you do. There are no challenges beyond comparing your score to the global leaderboards. Coupled with the very minimalist aesthetic, that makes this game look extremely empty. If I didn’t know better, I’d assume it was still in early access. Which it very well might be, since the developers are adding new features with the upcoming Zen edition. And honestly, to me there isn’t much incentive to doing something very limited over and over again.The devs also highlight car customization and free-roaming areas as features and these are just not enough. You get to paint your car in a few different colors and that’s it. Free-roam is just an empty overworld filled with “challenges” which boil down to “drift between these two objects”, “donut around an object”, “collect 5 items in this part of the map” and “jump over an object with a ramp”. And those last two highlight how little there actually is to do in a game that is only about drifting.Honestly, if this weren’t part of a Humble Bundle that contained games I was interested in more, I probably would’ve stayed away from this game. There’s just not much there to enjoy here for me. But I do have to wonder if the price of $12 is justifiable, even though I paid nowhere near as much. Because the aesthetic is – like the developers’ previous game Race The Sun – deliberately minimalist and only features low-poly objects with basically no textures applied to them. And I can’t believe that it took that much effort to create the gameplay, since most engines nowadays feature basic driving mechanics as prefabs. If you’re into games with a very narrow focus and can deal with the repetition or if you’re the type that has to be competitive 100% of the time, you’ll find something to enjoy in Absolute Drift. But I honestly couldn’t recommend it to anybody else, since it’s just too light on content to be anything substantial.

5/10 - Absolute Drift goes round and round and round and round...Drifting has always existed as a sort of accessory sport to traditional racing. Flashy and dangerous, drifting — the act of taking a corner so as to lose control of the back wheels and cause the car to turn sideways — prizes style and precision over speed and vehicular power. Though organized events such as the US’s Formula D series exist they are still searching for a large audience, and outside of Japan drifting remains largely a novelty, something to spice up action movies and arcade racers but rarely thought of as a legitimate sport itself.Absolute Drift (2015) feels in large part an attempt to move away from drifting as spectacle, giving you a car and a road and letting you figure out the rest. The presentation is stripped down to blunt polygonal buildings and red highlights to tell you where to go, with your car itself a nondescript toy-sized vehicle only visible by its bright paint job and lengthy tire tracks.When placed next to the gleeful excess of Need for Speed or the cartoony impossibility of Mario Kart, Absolute Drift singular focus is clean and consolidated. Drifting is the literal name of the game, so drift away to your heart’s content, careening through rectangular roads that only further emphasize the exacting grace of your curve.In a 1995 interview on Jeremy Clarkson’s Motorworld, drifting progenitor and legend Keiichi “Drift King” Tsuchiya says that one of the reasons he began drifting was to entertain the crowd during racing events. It was almost always assured he would win, so drifting became a way to put excitement back into a race where the outcome was no longer the reason to watch. This ideology is a key component to drifting’s popularity in media and as a spectator event. Watching cars go fast is fun, but watching cars go fast and take turns in ways that seem to defy the laws of physics is exhilarating.One of Absolute Drift’s earliest contradictions is in its reliance on traditional events and score attacks as means of creating a sense of progression. Absolute Drift’s prevailing methodology is that drifting is itself reward enough, and that the problem with the way drifting is used in other media is that it has become deluded by the obsessive adoration paid to it by movies like The Fast and the Furious: Tokyo Drift (2006). Drifting should be about the screech of your tires and the smoke of your skid marks, Absolute Drift seems to say as it positions drifting in an almost religious context (the game itself opens with a Shinto deity welcoming you into a sort of drift heaven).And yet here the game is asking you to do a donut around this building, or jump your car over this gap. The problem with Absolute Drift’s attempt at drifting solidarity is not that it doesn’t stick to that goal, but that it never could. As Zach Kotzer writes for Kill Screen, “drifting is not an absolute; it is a means to an end.” Absolute Drift needs its leaderboards and its car stunts because drifting in isolation just isn’t that interesting. Just as Tsuchiya incorporated drifting into his racing to spice up his corners, racing games have utilized drifting for the similar purpose of making themselves more interesting to play and watch.When you strip everything but drifting away from these games, sliding through corners begins to dull rather than excite. Absolute Drift may see drifting as an elevated form of racing, but there is a reason the sport has only ever garnered a niche audience. There are only so many ways you can drift the same turn before it starts to feel routine. This is a problem for games with far more robust handling systems than Absolute Drift can manage (your toy car feels like a boat cruising through a bowl of ice cream), which only exacerbates the problem as what is drifting but the precise understanding and control of a car’s grip and power.Absolute Drift’s devotion to a singular idea is compelling in its focus and clean production. Its sparse world is as easy on the eyes as the trance soundtrack is on the ears, and there is some fun to be had navigating these large sandboxes populated with fighter jets and Ferris Wheels. But that fun is akin to setting up a ramp and watching a Hot Wheels car fly down it, popping off the ground and begging you to do it again. Eventually you grow tired of this simple task and long for something more involving. But your toy is still just a Hot Wheels car, and this is still just a drifting game.You can find more of my writing on Kritiqal[kritiqal.com].

												Absolute Drift is a game about drifting.It emphasizes timing, focus, reflex, and a nuanced comprehension of steering and gearshifting mechanics. However, this game does not have any technical stats or car-classes that allow you to tailor a car or course to your style. One engine and suspension type, cosmetic chassis, locked top-down view. The real nitty-gritty aspects of Drift Racing are left out of this simplified expression of the art.Absolute Drift is a game about Zen. Revelations abound as you learn by tooling about in an openworld-style drifting playground, where you are enticed to push your skills and remove the training wheels in exchange for more precision and direct control. This teaches you patience and encourages clear-minded serenity to tackle multiplier challenges and exceptionally long drifts. Letting go, both of your ego and your break, transforms each turn into a slice of transcendent meditation. But there is more to Absolute Drift than letting go.Absolute Drift is a game about drive. The drive to turn each course into a masterpice, one gear-shift at a time. Rather than listed names and a ladder leaderboard, you are given global player percentages, and where you fall in the over all community based on each course and event you complete. More than that, the urge to paint the tarmac with sublime compass-curves and deft switch-back transitions. It motivates you so effortlessly that time and anxiety fade away in the clouds of rubber smoke trailing behind you.It's a good game.

												I genuinely wish I could give a neutral review for this one. The game is not bad. In fact, it is very good at what it does.Absolute Drift is a minimalist drifting game, in which you're a white (can change) car, in a white world, with white objects everywhere. Except for a few things. Orange colored objects are destroyable and/or important. Each "world" also seems to have another flavor color splashed in periodically. (i.e. Yellow in world 2, Blue in world 3, etc.) And each "world" you unlock by completing various "missions" (such as doing donuts, spins, drifting between obstacles, etc.). There are no time limits as far as I can tell, and it's just a very open-world (on a table top), relaxed, easy going drifting game with no rules, no conflict, and no consequences.All of that, it does EXTREMELY well. However, it is not FUN. At least not to me. I'm playing on an XBox controller, and I also tried it out on my keyboard. There's five controls. Gas/Accelerate, Brake/Reverse, Steering, and E-Brake. You can also remove automatic transmission and have another shift up/down pair of buttons available. But I found the shifting on this tedious, and without shifting the game is repetitive. You can learn to do all you can do within the first ten seconds of playing. Spinning only works in reverse as far as I can tell, and "donuts" are just, basically, a slow lazy drift. When you are told to donut something, you can get 10%, crash, and get 10% more, crash, and repeat until complete. I've played plenty of other racing games with drifting components, and a few other drifting-centered games. This one, you have significantly less control over your vehicle. And the way the game calculates a "drift" you can literally drive straight up to your obstacle and slam on your brakes and succeed in just about any of the "missions". There is no incentive I can tell to do well (other than placing higher in the global rankings), and no punishments if you just crash into a wall over and over until you succeed.To feel successful, one must suceed. To succeed, there must be a chance of failure. To avoid failure, one must learn. Learning is caused by either positive or negative reinforcement, or some combination. This game has none. Perhaps I just suck at this game, but I didn't find it fun.TL;DR: If you want a laid-back drifting game with no clear rules, where you can just drive around a pristine environment to your hearts content, this is for you. Otherwise, look elsewhere.#TOFU #JDM #HOONEDIT: It doesn't seem to be recording my time correctly. Anyone who's played it knows it takes longer than "0.1 hours" to get that far.

												Absolute Drift is a lot of fun.  Once you get a hang of the controls, you'll be drifting along effortlessly and feel just a little bit like Fujiwara Takumi.The game has 3 modes: Drift Track, Driftkhana, Mountain.  Each presented in a clean, minimal look and feel, which in my mind, enhances your experience since there's no distraction from what this game is about: Drifting.Drift track is simply what is says: a track to drift around.Driftkhana can be said to be a timed playground with boxes to knock over, demarcated areas to spin in, make doughnuts and just in general do as many drift tricks as you can in the set amount of time.Mountain is similar to Drift track, only the "track" mimics a mountain downhill where you traverse it from end to finish.The aim in each of the modes: score the as many points as possible.At first this is quite difficult as you get to grips with the car and the handling.  But the controls are forgiving, as are the physics.  Soon you'll learn the limits of the car and the ins and outs of the handling and physics together, throwing the car around like second nature.Furthermore, connecting all of the events, are hub areas (5 in total), each containing between 18 and 25 missions to complete.  Complete all missions in an area to unlock the next.You can also access all of the events from the main menu and jump straight in if you like ( no need to unlock them first ).Absolute drift is great for simply relaxing and pouring out any stress you have into the satisfying act of watching a micro-machine sized car, drift around corners, boxes, containers and trains.Highly recommended.NOTE: Absolute drift is purely a singleplayer experience.  Don't approach if you this is a drift racing game.

												Absolute Drift is a game about drifting.It emphasizes timing, focus, reflex, and a nuanced comprehension of steering and gearshifting mechanics. However, this game does not have any technical stats or car-classes that allow you to tailor a car or course to your style. One engine and suspension type, cosmetic chassis, locked top-down view. The real nitty-gritty aspects of Drift Racing are left out of this simplified expression of the art.Absolute Drift is a game about Zen. Revelations abound as you learn by tooling about in an openworld-style drifting playground, where you are enticed to push your skills and remove the training wheels in exchange for more precision and direct control. This teaches you patience and encourages clear-minded serenity to tackle multiplier challenges and exceptionally long drifts. Letting go, both of your ego and your break, transforms each turn into a slice of transcendent meditation. But there is more to Absolute Drift than letting go.Absolute Drift is a game about drive. The drive to turn each course into a masterpice, one gear-shift at a time. Rather than listed names and a ladder leaderboard, you are given global player percentages, and where you fall in the over all community based on each course and event you complete. More than that, the urge to paint the tarmac with sublime compass-curves and deft switch-back transitions. It motivates you so effortlessly that time and anxiety fade away in the clouds of rubber smoke trailing behind you.It's a good game.

Each presented in a clean, minimal look and feel, which in my mind, enhances your experience since there's no distraction from what this game is about: Drifting.Drift track is simply what is says: a track to drift around.Driftkhana can be said to be a timed playground with boxes to knock over, demarcated areas to spin in, make doughnuts and just in general do as many drift tricks as you can in the set amount of time.Mountain is similar to Drift track, only the "track" mimics a mountain downhill where you traverse it from end to finish.The aim in each of the modes: score the as many points as possible.At first this is quite difficult as you get to grips with the car and the handling.  But the controls are forgiving, as are the physics.  Soon you'll learn the limits of the car and the ins and outs of the handling and physics together, throwing the car around like second nature.Furthermore, connecting all of the events, are hub areas (5 in total), each containing between 18 and 25 missions to complete.  Complete all missions in an area to unlock the next.You can also access all of the events from the main menu and jump straight in if you like ( no need to unlock them first ).Absolute drift is great for simply relaxing and pouring out any stress you have into the satisfying act of watching a micro-machine sized car, drift around corners, boxes, containers and trains.Highly recommended.NOTE: Absolute drift is purely a singleplayer experience.  Don't approach if you this is a drift racing game.

												Great art direction - minimalistic, soft colors, and sharp edges combine into a pleasing visual experience. Tire tracks show your course and how to replicate it (or not). No matter what I do the controller pulls to the left constantly.The fixes for the XONE controller are hit and miss - works for some, doesn't work for others, but they are just workarounds. A game like this needs inherent support for controllers. My DS4 controller did not work either.I'm hesitant to recommend Absolute Drift. I had a lot of fun before I switched to the current generation of controllers. I would avoid this game if you use the current controllers; if you use a 360 controller or use KB/M (I would recommend not to), then you should be fine.EDIT: The developer supplied a beta version of the newest build of the game and it solved my control issues.
